qas.question: What occupy a more or less space area?
What can sometimes be translated as tetragraph?

context: Just as <a0_0>Roman letters<a0_0/> have a characteristic shape (lower-case letters mostly occupying the x-height, with ascenders or descenders on some letters), <a1_0>Chinese characters<a1_0/> occupy a more or less square area in which the components of every character are written to fit in order to maintain a uniform size and shape, especially with small printed characters in Ming and sans-serif styles. Because of this, beginners often practise writing on squared graph paper, and the Chinese sometimes use the term "<a2_0>Square-Block Characters<a2_0/>" (方块字 / 方塊字, fāngkuàizì), sometimes translated as tetragraph, in reference to Chinese characters.
